text: NT Practice I guess the number 720 is just awesome. 1. (JSteinhardt) Let ⋄(k) be the sum of k’s digits in base 720 + 1. How many positive integers m exist such that ⋄(k) ≡ k (mod m) for all k? We will separate digits base 721 by grouping them with parentheses for clariﬁcation purposes. First we can see that any divisor of 720 works, since 721n ≡ 1 (mod m) if m|720. In addition, we can see that it is necessary that m is a divisor of 720 by noting that in particular (1)(1)721 ≡ 2721 (mod m), so (720)721 ≡ 0 (mod m) =⇒ m|720. Then it only remains to ﬁnd the number of divisors of 720 = 6! = 6 ∗ 5 ∗ 4 ∗ 3 ∗ 2 = 3 ∗ 2 ∗ 5 ∗ 2 ∗ 2 ∗ 3 ∗ 2 = 5 ∗ 32 ∗ 24, so there can be between 0 and 1 powers of 5, 0 and 2 powers of 3, and 0 and 4 powers of 2 that divide any factor of 720, leading to 2 ∗ 3 ∗ 5 = 30 factors. 2. (JSteinhardt) Find the number of divisors of the sum of the squares of the divisors of 720. The sum of the squares of the divisors of 720 can be found similarly to the sum of the divisors of 720. That is, since 720 = 5 ∗ 32 ∗ 24 (shown above), we can use the factorization (12 + 52)(12 + 32 + 92)(12 + 22 + 42 + 82 + 162) (do you see why this works?) and simplify this to 6 ∗ 91 ∗ 341 = 2 ∗ 3 ∗ 7 ∗ 13 ∗ 11 ∗ 31 and use the same logic as before to deduce that there are 32 divisors to this number. 3. (JSteinhardt) Find the sum of the square divisors of 720. We again use a factorization, this time ignoring any factors that aren’t squares. The resulting form is (1) ∗ (1 + 32) ∗ (1 + 22 + 24) = 10 ∗ 21 = 210 . Actually, 210 is pretty cool as well. 4. (Traditional) Find the right-most non-zero digit of 210! in base 210. First we note that 210 = 2 ∗ 3 ∗ 5 ∗ 7. The largest factor of 210 that divides 210! will therefore correspond to the largest factor of 7 that divides 210!, which is ⌊ 210 7 ⌋+⌊ 210 49 ⌋+. . . = 30+4 = 34. Starting with 5 and 7, we get that it is 10 mod 35. Bringing in 3, we have that it is 45 mod 105. Finally, bringing in 2 gives that it is 150 mod 210, so the answer is 150 . 5. (Traditional) Find the smallest positive integer n such that 1n + 2n + . . . + 46n is not divisible by 47. Let g be a generator mod 47. Then {g1, . . . , g46} is equivalent to the set {1, . . . , 46} be deﬁnition. Thus, 46∑ i=1 i n = 46∑ i=1 gin, which is now an easily evaluatable geometric series that is in particular congruent to 0 mod 47 for any n < 46. It is then clear from Fermat’s theorem that it is not congruent to 0 for n = 46, so the answer is 46 . And ﬁnally, Haitao has asked permission to give you all a problem, and I said yes. 8.
